This article uses citations that link to broken or outdated sources. Please improve the article or discuss this issue on the talk page. Help on using footnotes is available. (November 2015) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)
One Piece discography
The One Piece logo, as seen on many of the series' CD covers
Compilation albums 8
Singles 51
Soundtrack albums 17

A number of musical CDs have been created for the media franchise built around Eiichirō Oda's manga One Piece. Various theme songs and character songs were released on a total of 49 singles. Many of them were also released in collected form on the eight compilation albums or the 16 soundtrack CDs, along with background music from the anime television series, the series' feature films, and video games.

The anime television series currently consists of 36 pieces of theme music; eighteen opening themes and eighteen ending themes. As of episode 279, ending themes were omitted and, starting from episode 326 onwards, opening themes were extended from 110 seconds long to 150 seconds long. In episodes 1-206 of Funimation's English-language release of the series, the opening and ending themes were dubbed into English by various voice actors, before reverting to the Japanese versions from episodes 207 onwards.

The sub-lists on compilation albums and singles list the releases peak position in Oricon's weekly charts as well as the length of the release's chart run in weeks.

  • 2 Singles
  • 3 Soundtracks

Peak Weeks
1999 "We Are!" (ウィーアー!, Wī Ā!)
  • Released: November 20, 1999
  • Label: Columbia Music Entertainment
  • Won the Animation Kobe Theme Song Award of the year 2000[9]
  • Used as opening theme for episodes 1–47, the television special, Umi no Heso no Dai Bouken, and the feature film, One Piece: The Movie
  • A cover version by the Straw Hat Pirates is used as opening theme for episodes 279–283. (Opening 7)
  • A cover version by TVXQ is used as opening theme for episodes 373–394. (Opening 10)
  • Dubbed into English by Vic Mignogna for the Funimation release.

Reception[edit]

Carl Kimlinger of Anime News Network states that "One Piece has always stood out for its use of music", which they describe as a "usual mix of trumpeting pirate bombast, rocking action music, and catchy individual themes".[78] Margaret Veira of Active Anime states that the anime television series's "background music sets the mood and the scenes perfectly."[79]
